summary: finnish researchers compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year olds with records on antibiotic prescription . by two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese . children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight . repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler .

finnish researchers compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year olds with records on antibiotic prescription . by two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese . children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight . repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler .

finnish researchers compared the weight and height of more than 12,000 healthy two year olds with records on antibiotic prescription . by two years-old, one in five boys and one in ten girls was overweight or obese . children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight . repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler .
aspect: 1. Babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, according to a large-scale study.
2. The widely-prescribed drugs may contribute to the obesity epidemic, as one-third of 10-11 year olds and more than one-fifth of 4-5 year olds in England are overweight or obese.

3. The Finnish researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with antibiotic prescription records. Children who had received antibiotics before two years of age were particularly prone to weight gain.
explain: 1. Infant babies who received antibiotics during their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, based on a large-scale study.

The overuse and misuse of antibiotics early in life could be a contributing factor to the obesity epidemic, with one-third of 10-11 year olds and over one-fifth of 4-5 year olds in England being overweight or obese.

The study examined 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and analyzed their weight and height. Children taking antibiotics before their second birthday were more likely to become overweight. Repeated prescriptions before two also increased the chance of being overweight.
